title: Common Trees of the North Carolina Piedmont
subTitle: Version: March 7, 2006

characters.name: <common names>
data: <southern sugar maple, Florida maple, hammock maple>
<box elder, ash leaved maple, boxelder, Texas box elder, eastern box elder>
<red maple, carolina maple, eastern red maple, scarlet maple>
<southern shagbark hickory, Carolina shagbark hickory, Carolina hickory>
<pignut hickory, hairy pignut hickory, sweet pignut>
<American beech, beech, gray beech, red beech, white beech>
<eastern red-cedar, coastal red-cedar, red-cedar, southern red-cedar>
<black gum, black tupelo, pepperidge, sour gum>
<hop hornbeam, American hop hornbeam, Eastern hop hornbeam, ironwood>
<shortleaf pine, short-leaf pine, rosemary pine, yellow pine>
<loblolly pine, old field pine, short leaf pine>
<Virginia pine, Jersey pine, poverty pine, scrub pine>
<black cherry, rum cherry, wild black cherry>
<white oak, eastern white oak, northern white oak>
<chestnut oak, mountain chestnut oak, rock chestnut oak>

characters.name: synonyms
data: <\i{}Acer barbatum\i0{} var. \i{}longii \i0{}(Fern.) Fern., \i{}Acer floridanum \i0{}(Chapman) Pax, \i{}Acer saccharum\i0{} Marsh. ssp. \i{}floridanum \i0{}(Chapman) Desmarais, \i{}Saccharodendron floridanum \i0{}(Chapman) Nieuwl.>
<\i{}Acer negundo\i0{} var. \i{}texanum\i0{} Pax, \i{}Negundo aceroides\i0{} (L.) Moench, \i{}Negundo negundo\i0{} (L.) Karst.>
<\i{}Acer rubrum\i0{} var. \i{}trilobum\i0{} Torr. & Gray ex K. Koch, \i{}Rufacer rubrum\i0{} (L.) Small>
<\i{}Carpinus caroliniana\i0{} ssp. \i{}caroliniana\i0{} (Marsh.) Furlow, \i{}Carpinus caroliniana\i0{} var.\i{}virginiana\i0{} (Marsh.) Fern.>
<\i{}Carya tomentosa\i0{} (Lam. ex. Poir.) Nutt., \i{}Hicoria alba\i0{} (L.) Britt.>

<\i{}Carya australis\i0{} Ashe, \i{}Carya ovata\i0{} (P. Mill.) K. Koch var. \i{}australis\i0{} (Ashe) Little, \i{}Carya ovata\i0{} (P. Mill.) K. Koch var. \i{}carolinae-septentrionalis\i0{} (Ashe) Reveal, \i{}Hicoria carolinae-septentrionalis\i0{} Ashe>

<\i{}Carya glabra \i0{}var. \i{}hirsuta\i0{} (Ashe) Ashe, \i{}Carya glabra \i0{}var. \i{}megacarpa\i0{} (Sarg.) Sarg., \i{}Hicoria glabra \i0{}(P. Mill.) Britt., \i{}Hicoria microcarpa \i0{}(Nutt.) Britt.>

<\i{}Fraxinus darlingtonii \i0{}Britt., \i{}Fraxinus pennsylvanica\i0{} var. \i{}austinii \i0{}Fern., \i{}Fraxinus pennsylvanica\i0{} var. \i{}subintegerrima\i0{} (Vahl) Fern., \i{}Fraxinus smallii \i0{}Britt.>
<\i{}Nyssa sylvatica\i0{} var. \i{}caroliniana\i0{} (Poir.) Fern., \i{}Nyssa sylvatica\i0{} var. \i{}dilatata\i0{} Fern.>
<\i{}Quercus digitata\i0{} Sudworth, \i{}Quercus falcata\i0{} var. \i{}triloba\i0{} (Michx.) Nutt., \i{}Quercus triloba\i0{} Michx.>

<\i{}Quercus borealis \i0{}Michx. f., \i{}Quercus borealis\i0{} var. \i{}maxima \i0{}(Marsh.) Ashe, \i{}Quercus maxima \i0{}(Marsh.) Ashe, \i{}Quercus rubra\i0{} var. \i{}ambigua\i0{} (A. Gray) Fern., \i{}Quercus rubra\i0{} var. \i{}borealis\i0{} (Michx. f.) Farw.>

characters.name: plants <major group - i.e., gymnosperm or angiosperm>
twigs (2-4 years old) <special surface features - i.e., scaly, spiny, winged, etc.>
bud clusters at ends of twigs <presence>
bud scales <type - i.e., imbricate, valvate, etc.>
leaves <duration - i.e., evergreen, semi-evergreen, or deciduous>
leaves <general form - i.e., broad-leaved, needle-like, or scale-like>
leaves <form of attachment - i.e., petiolate, nearly sessile, or sessile>
leaf margins <form - i.e., entire, dentate, etc.>
leaves <lobing - i.e., unlobed, shallowly lobed, etc.>
leaves <lobing form - i.e., palmate or pinnate>
leaf venation <form - i.e., palmate, pinnate, etc.>
leaflets <form of attachment - i.e., petiolulate, nearly sessile, or sessile>
leaflet margins <form - i.e., entire, dentate, etc.>
leaflet venation <form - i.e., palmate, pinnate, etc.>
petioles <special surface features - i.e., scaly, spiny, winged, etc.>
rachises <special surface features - i.e., scaly, spiny, winged, etc.>
flowers <form of attachment - i.e., sessile, nearly sessile, or stalked>
seed cones <seed release - i.e., cones opening or remaining closed>
seed cones <form of attachment - i.e., sessile, nearly sessile, or stalked>
seed cone scales <type - i.e., fleshy, leathery, or woody>
seed cone scales <armature - i.e., armed or unarmed>

taxa.name: \i{}Paulownia tomentosa\i0{} <(Thunb.) Sieb. & Zucc. ex Steud.> (Princess tree)
